comments.commentBody: Perhaps I am just not recalling but it seems Elizabeth Keckley didn't write about this period of D.C. in her memoir-novel.  She'd finally gotten the money together to stay in D.C. past the 60 day limit for free people of color in 1860.  She'd met Mary Lincoln March 1st and gotten the accolade of being named the First Lady's modiste. Keckley's accounts of other historical moments, these non-fiction parts, have been illuminating, so this would be too -- the account of a free woman of color faced with the potential of having a CSA army take D.C.  Perhaps she too, wisely, left the city for the duration of the threat?
So much for the South's contention that they were just defending their country from the Union in the War of Northern Aggression.

I can't imagine the fear that newly-freed or born-free African-Americans must have felt knowing that were they taken prisoner, they would be sent back to their former (or new) owners down South and re-enslaved or brutally killed as examples.  This "Disunion" series, perhaps more than anything, continually provides evidence that the Southern states' idea of "states' rights" was all about maintaining slavery and their belief in the inferiority of African-Americans.  (Just like Thomas Jefferson, the hero of "states' rights)

Commenter #3, I hope no-one answers your question immediately because it would spoil things for some of us. This series is a wonderful way to experience history just because we have to watch developing events at the same pace as those who originally lived them. I know that it would be a simple task to grab a book off the shelf or use "The Google" to get a quick answer to our questions, but then we just might miss out on capturing the Zeitgeist of the people and places of that period. Nice series, NYT.
too bad the south didnt capture washington dc, cut a peace treaty and validation of their secession as a constitutional right and leave.

I too wondered why the Confederate Army had not invaded Washington. So I looked it up. It seems there was an attempt, but please don't ask me the particulars since I am not able to follow anything about battles.
The attempt was stopped. For whatever reason it is something little known about the Civil War.
Ruth Beazer

In answer to #3, simply there was an awareness that the South could attack but there was a lack of a central authority and government at that point in the history of the Confederacy, and this inability to develop a central and credible leadership remained a problem facing the Confederacy both practically and intellectually: i.e., a belief in the primacy of individual state's rights will inevitably impede the ability of the national government to act quickly and decisively.

The South attacked at every early opportunity, except the correct one.  Its only hope of ever winning the war lay in attacking and taking Washington early on.    Pride cometh before a fall.  They waited, built an army, selected the finest Generals in the land, then marched off in force against an enemy they had absolutely no chance to defeat through sheer force of massed arms.  How lucky for the USA.
Imitate a hot dog was my favourite!!

“Make a prisoner of war” = INTERN (8/6/05); “Prisoner of war, e.g.” (4/30/99), “P.O.W.” (12/8/00), “John McCain, e.g., for over five years” (4/22/11) = INTERNEE: prisoners of war are not interned. When soldiers fall into the hands of the enemy, they are prisoners of war. They are internees when they fall into the hands of a neutral power; American bomber crews forced to land in Sweden or Switzerland during the Second World War, for instance, were interned until the war was over; cf. “Detain during wartime” = INTERN (3/13/97; NB: “detain” not “imprison”).

Curt@42:  you raise an interesting consideration:  regional dialects and pronunciation.  Is it possible for two words to sound the same in one part of the US but not in another?  For example, yawn and yarn might be homophones in Boston.

I live on the second floor of a three-floor apartment building. For a while, my husband and I (who are childless) had a family with two small children living above us. The running back and forth could get tiresome, and the crying at night often made it difficult to fall asleep, but we shrugged and said "They're kids, what can we do?" and never really considered making a noise complaint.

It was also kind of nice to see the kids grow as we passed our neighbors on the stairs or in the parking lot. We never exchanged names, but I knew their car, and often I saw them playing on the grass as I came home from work.

They've since moved out and I have no idea who the people above me are, other than they have a tendency to play video games and I think have a subwoofer over our heads. Frankly, I'd rather have this couple than the kids before; our current upstairs neighbors are *usually* quieter (except for that one night).

But the kids had their own charms.

Another sign of the economy.  Green products and organics are too expensive except for the wealthy elite

At our very green company, Equal Exchange, sales for our dual certified organic/Fair Trade products (coffee, tea, chocolate, bananas) have continued to grow every year. And that parallels the pattern nationwide for the $25+ billion organic market and the $1 billion Fair Trade products market.  So - given that, and the good results for _thoroughly green companies_ like Method& 7th Generation, my conclusion is that the overall market for green products (at least those sold in grocery stores) continues to grow, despite the recession, and that what the reporters have captured are the mixed results of conventional corporations who are, basically, johnny-come-lately's to the green marketplace.

It is a great pity that more environmentally "friendly" (or less environmentally destructive) goods are usually much more expensive than the non-"green" products. Just as the government subsidizes farmers (a whole 'nother topic), I believe that companies that produce and sell less-toxic, less-polluting goods and services should be rewarded with lower taxes (provided the quality and genuine benefits are constantly monitored and verified by an independent agency).
Same with verifiable organic food (held to the highest standards): most people I know can't afford them even though we would certainly like to support, buy, and eat them.
If "green" and organic products and produce are made sufficiently affordable, believe me, people will buy them.

Many people who used green products have found they can make their own versions cheaply. For example, I found--I believe from Consumers Report--that mixing vinegar and water to clean fruits and vegetables was better and certainly easier and cheaper than the product I'd been buying. And Costco now has an inexpensive green dishwashing liquid so I've given up Method.  Things may be more complex than your article indicates.

Vinegar, baking soda and water do most jobs. I went green by not buying any of this stuff in the first place. It's still sold in plastic bottles and transported across the country via truck. The packaging and delivery was just as toxic. I reuse an empty spray cleaner bottle and refill it. We've managed to survive as a species for a few generations before the all consuming need to disinfect everything as if it were an operating room.

Maybe if people knew about all the toxic chemicals in many of the "mainstream" cleaning products, they would see the green, less toxic products in a different light. Personally, I have become very chemical sensitive and cannot tolerate the chemicals in such products as Fantastik. It always gave me a sore throat, now it also gives me a headache. I have always wondered what the heck is in these products!? They can't be good for us OR mother nature. Maybe it is  pay a little more now or pay a lot more later as medical bills.
More than fine with me if most of those products disappeared and never came back. Most green products are inferior in performance as well as more expensive.

I only buy "green" products. I just don't buy them from what I perceive to be large corporations because I lost my trust in anything they say. In fact, when they say "green" I assume it's not.

Similar to the USDA certifying "Organic." Once Monstanto and other powers had their way with that label, I wrote off USDA Organic and now try to stick with Oregon Tithe.

If these companies want to win trust they need to educate the public about their integrity and then show some by sticking with their "green" products -- for the right reasons. In the end they will benefit and so will their grandchildren.
